sub_topic: Time dilation in a moving frame of reference
message_1: A spaceship is traveling at a velocity of 0.8c relative to the Earth. How much longer will one year on the spaceship seem to an astronaut on board compared to a person on Earth? (Assuming time dilation in a moving frame of reference according to the theory of special relativity).
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the time dilation formula from the theory of special relativity:

Δt' = Δt / √(1 - v^2/c^2)

where Δt' is the time experienced by the astronaut on the spaceship (proper time), Δt is the time experienced by the person on Earth, v is the relative velocity of the spaceship (0.8c), and c is the speed of light.

First, we need to find the factor √(1 - v^2/c^2):

√(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2) = √(1 - 0.64) = √(0.36) = 0.6

Now, we can use this factor to find the time experienced by the astronaut on the spaceship:

Δt' = Δt / 0.6

Since we want to find how much longer one year on the spaceship seems to the astronaut compared to the person on Earth, we can set Δt = 1 year:

Δt' = 1 year / 0.6 ≈ 1.67 years

So, one year on the spaceship will seem approximately 1.67 years to the astronaut on board compared to a person on Earth.
